22:20 <sable> has joined #xwiki  
22:22 <sable> hello. i'm looking to set up a page which will contain information that i collect from a farm of servers. serial numbers, amount of RAM and stuff like that. How can I push content in an automated fashion to a wiki page?  
22:24 <sable> I'm happy to organize in several pages or one huge page or whatever is easiest. I think perhaps what I'm trying to do isn't commonly done with Wiki software out there as I'm having trouble finding anything relevant from other wiki software as well.  
22:33 <rrodriguez> has joined #xwiki  
22:39 <@cjdelisle> i think the easiest thing to do is have the page query the servers when you load the page  
22:39 <@cjdelisle> using scripting  
22:39 <@cjdelisle> I'm not sure how you collect the information but you do things like http requests from scripting.  
22:41 <sable> So I'd write a script within an XWiki page, which probes for information on a server? I'd have to write some code that would respond to the XWiki query as opposed to attempting to do an HTTP PUT or something?  
22:42 <sable> Ideally I collect the information in diagnostic bundles. I am free to present information from these bundles in any way I want.  
22:46 <@cjdelisle> I see  
22:46 <@cjdelisle> so you want your diagnostic code to run periodicly and then publish?  
22:48 <sable> Yes, that's about how I was approaching this. But that's not to say that's the best way. Its a good way though because if I add the diagnostic dump tool to a host, it would automagically appear as another server in the XWiki  
22:49 <@cjdelisle> You could have it do an http request which calls some wiki code and that code takes the parameters and adds an object to a wiki page for your server. Then on the display side the page with the objects has some code which displays statistics based on what "server objects" are linked to that page.  
22:49 <sable> It's certainly possible to do it the other way around, but I'd have to convince the XWiki to query the diagnostic framework somehow to pick up additional servers…  
22:50 <pturcotte> has joined #xwiki  
22:50 <@cjdelisle> if you did it in reverse then it would be on a "pre page load" basis  
22:50 <@cjdelisle> \*per page load  
22:53 <sable> OK so if I wrote a Groovy script, I'd have an HTTP PUT call that script (from the client), then this script would call a handle to dig through a given diagnostic dump.  
22:54 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki  
22:54 <sable> Then collect given tuplets and return them as objects  
22:54 <sable> is that about a reasonable approach?  
22:54 <@cjdelisle> Yes  
22:55 <sable> OK, I think I can manage the rest with the API docs… Thanks for the help!  
22:55 <@cjdelisle> and it would get the display page, manipulate the objects in that page, and then save it.  
22:55 <@cjdelisle> !search xwiki scripting  
22:55 <vmassol> has quit  
22:56 <@cjdelisle> http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/DevGuide/Scripting  
22:56 <sable> The API seems pretty rich and with Groovy I seem to have nearly everything I need  
22:56 <@cjdelisle> that's a good starting point  
22:56 <sable> Yeah I'm already perusing it  
22:57 <@cjdelisle> this project can be done from either velocity or groovy so it's your choice.  
22:57 <sable> I suppose Velocity would be less exposing  
22:59 <sable> ListTool seems pretty powerful and might sufficient for a large part of this  
22:59 <@cjdelisle> Velocity has security advantages (you can run it with less permission) but if it's an internal site then it's basicly your call.  
22:59 <sable> Its an internal site, but since its an automated process its usually better to make do with fewer permissions if possible  
23:01 <sable> Thanks for the info  
23:02 <@cjdelisle> sure thing
